articles.title: "CBS Weekend News" headlines for Sunday, November 25, 2018
articles.description: Here's a look at the top stories making headlines on the "CBS Weekend News" with Elaine Quijano.

articles.title: Blizzard warnings hamper busy holiday weekend travel
articles.description: On the busiest travel day of the holiday weekend, blizzard warnings stretch through the heart of the country from the Great Plains to the Great Lakes. Snow isn't the only threat as powerful wind advisories are posted from Texas to Illinois. Whiteout condition…

articles.title: Rough weather causes major delays at Midwest airports
articles.description: The brutal weather is disrupting travel plans for many headed home after the holiday weekend. Hundreds of flights into and out of the storm zone have been grounded. CBS News correspondent Meg Oliver reports.

articles.title: Fukushima: Three years later
articles.description: Bob Simon reports on the aftermath of the disaster in Fukushima, Japan, and finds toxic ghost towns frozen in time

articles.title: EYE ON TECH: VOICE-CONTROLLED MICROWAVE

articles.title: Trump seeks to alter policy for asylum-seekers
articles.description: President Trump is seeking to change the policy for asylum-seekers at the U.S.-Mexico border. Meanwhile, the Group of 20 summit will convene this week, and an associate of Roger Stone's is in plea talks with special counsel Robert Mueller. Susan Page, Washing…

articles.title: Critics accuse Trump of burying climate report
articles.description: A new government report on climate change predicts dire consequences for the United States. Jake Levine, a former Obama administration energy and climate aide, joined CBSN to discuss the implications of the assessment.

articles.description: Aaron Sorkin and Jeff Daniels tell "60 Minutes" how the theme of racial injustice resonates today — and the emotional scene not included in Sorkin's play
articles.content: Last month, PBS announced that Harper Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird was voted by viewers as "America's best-loved novel." But writer Aaron Sorkin told 60 Minutes that, when he began adapting the Southern classic for the Broadway stage, he wasn't afraid to tweak… [+4878 chars]

articles.title: Fukushima's ghost towns
articles.description: More than seven years after one of the worst nuclear disasters in history, towns around Japan's nuclear power plant struggle to rebuild
articles.content: The streets are motionless. Items hang untouched on clotheslines, bleached by the sun. A clock shows 2:46, and it always will. More than seven years after an earthquake and tsunami caused a meltdown at a nuclear power plant in Japan's Fukushima prefecture, su… [+1876 chars]

articles.title: Robots to the rescue after nuclear disaster
articles.description: Seven years after a powerful earthquake and tsunami caused a massive nuclear meltdown in the Daiichi Power Plant, Lesley Stahl reports on the unprecedented cleanup effort
articles.content: More than seven years have passed since a monster earthquake and tsunami struck northeast Japan and triggered what became, after Chernobyl, the worst nuclear disaster in history at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant. When three of its six reactors melt… [+12011 chars]

articles.title: 11/25: Trey Gowdy, Angus King, Bernie Sanders
articles.description: This week on Face the Nation, moderator Margaret Brennan interviews Sen. Bernie Sanders, Sen. Angus King, and Rep. Trey Gowdy. Plus, we will walk through the future of the U.S. in space with NASA's Steven Clarke, who heads the agency's exploration efforts.

articles.title: NASA’s Steve Clarke says we might see manned missions to Mars by late 2030
articles.description: The Deputy Associate Administrator for Exploration at NASA Steven Clark joins Margaret Brennan to discuss NASA’s latest mission to Mars and the future of space exploration.

articles.title: Sen. Sanders is confident legislation to stop U.S. support of Saudi Arabia in Yemen will pass
articles.description: Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vermont, joins Margaret Brennan to discuss the Climate Change report and pulling back support for Saudi Arabia in the war in Yemen.

articles.description: Sen. Angus King, I-Maine, joins Margaret Brennan to discuss the decision to send troops to protect the border and the investigation into the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.

articles.title: Open: This is Face the Nation, November 25th
articles.description: This week on Face the Nation, moderator Margaret Brennan interviews Sen. Bernie Sanders, Sen. Angus King, and Rep. Trey Gowdy. Plus, we will walk through the future of the U.S. in space with NASA's Steven Clarke, who heads the agency's exploration efforts.

articles.title: Rep. Gowdy wants James Comey’s deposition taped and made public
articles.description: Rep. Trey Gowdy, R-South Carolina, joins Margaret Brennan to discuss how to make Former FBI Director James Comey’s deposition public and Ivanka Trump’s emails.

articles.content: A Dallas real estate agent who was on life support with brain damage after she traveled to a clinic in Mexico last month for several plastic surgery procedures has died, her attorney said Saturday. Laura Avila was moved to hospice care earlier this month. "So… [+1021 chars]

articles.title: Giving thanks: A.J. Jacobs on his gratitude journey
articles.description: Commentator and columnist A.J. Jacobs, author of "Thanks a Thousand: A Gratitude Journey," describes the delightful trouble he went through to thank everyone who helped create his morning cup of coffee.

articles.title: John Prine, the "Singing Mailman," delivers again
articles.description: John Prine started writing songs while delivering mail in Chicago in the late 1960s. Over the last 50 years, classic tunes just seemed to pour out of him – some sad, like "Angel From Montgomery" and "Sam Stone"; some funny, like "Illegal Smile" and "In Spite …

articles.title: Calendar: Week of November 26
articles.description: "Sunday Morning" takes a look at some notable events of the week ahead. Lee Cowan reports.

articles.title: Gary Hart: "All the rules have changed" in politics
articles.description: The new movie "The Front Runner" focuses on how, in 1987, the presidential campaign of Colorado Senator Gary Hart was upended by a newspaper story raising allegations of an extramarital affair. In a rare television interview, Hart talks with Rita Braver about…

articles.title: Nature: Colorado mountains
articles.description: "Sunday Morning" takes you this morning to the San Juan Mountains near Durango, Colorado. Videographer: Scot Miller

articles.title: Thanks for the help of a loving neighbor
articles.description: For many people flooded out of their homes in and around Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, the most welcoming port in the storm has been a total stranger. Jaret Hucks, who owns the Midtown Inn and Cottages, has given away almost a thousand free nights to this com…

articles.title: The history of waterbeds
articles.description: People fell hard for waterbeds when the aqua-filled bedding was introduced half a century ago, but waterbed sales have tanked since their high-point in the 1980s, when about one in every five beds sold in America was a waterbed. Luke Burbank interviews Charli…

articles.title: Almanac: Andrew Carnegie
articles.description: On November 25, 1835, the steel industrialist and philanthropist Andrew Carnegie was born in Scotland. Lee Cowan reports.

articles.title: Introducing Alessia Cara
articles.description: The Canadian singer-songwriter, a recent Grammy-winner for Best New Artist, talks to correspondent Lee Cowan about her new album, "The Pains of Growing," and of adjusting to the destabilizing effects of fame.

articles.title: Edmund De Waal's poetry, in porcelain and on the page
articles.description: Artist Edmund de Waal creates a kind of tactile poetry with the thousands of porcelain pots he creates in his South London studio. But he's probably even better known for "The Hare With Amber Eyes," a very personal family history which has sold more than a mi…

articles.title: The truth behind conspiracy theories
articles.description: Human beings are skeptical of coincidence, and think in terms of cause-and-effect, which is why many people are attracted to conspiracy theories to explain seemingly inexplicable events, like the assassination of a U.S. President. Susan Spencer talks with spy…

articles.description: Four years after his death, a family feud erupts over radio legend Casey Kasem, exactly how he died and who was responsible -- an estate that could be worth $100 million is at stake. "48 Hours" Peter Van Sant reports.

articles.description: Friends, Gonzalo Venecia, Chuck and Eileen Olsen, and Les Martens remember the man behind the famous voice who kept "reaching for the stars."

articles.description: Radio icon Casey Kasem's daughters Julie and Kerri Kasem and wife Jean Kasem know Casey as more than a celebrity.

articles.title: Phil Mickelson defeats Tiger Woods in matchup for $9M prize
articles.description: Phil Mickelson defeated Tiger Woods in a on the 22nd hole of the day in the highly-touted "The Match." Mickelson took home $9 million for the win.

articles.description: Heavy snow and strong winds expected to cause airport delays in Central U.S.; Prince Harry, Duchess Meghan are moving out of Kensington Palace.

articles.title: "I thought... this is my last day": California wildfire survivor recalls running through flames
articles.description: The death toll from the worst wildfire in California history has climbed to at least 84. Carter Evans spoke to one survivor.

articles.title: Mexican government discussing new proposal for migrants coming to the U.S. with Trump administration
articles.description: Under a new proposal being discussed by Mexico and the U.S., thousands of migrants seeking asylum in the U.S. would have to stay in Mexico while their cases are processed in American courts. Weijia Jiang reports.

articles.title: Prince Harry, Duchess Meghan are moving out of Kensington Palace
articles.description: Prince Harry and Duchess Meghan are moving from Kensington Palace in London to a cottage in the country. The nesting newlyweds are moving early next year into "Frogmore Cottage" on the grounds of the Royal Windsor estate, where they were married. Harry and Me…

articles.title: Students who appeared to make Nazi salute in photo won’t be punished due to free speech
articles.description: School officials in Baraboo, Wisconsin say a group of boys will not be punished after appearing to make a Nazi salute in a prom photo. The photo went viral earlier this month and was condemned worldwide. In a letter to parents, an administrator said the boys'…

articles.title: How retail stores are reinventing holiday shopping using technology
articles.description: During this busy shopping season, the retail experience is being revolutionized. Stores are using technology to make it easier for shoppers to find, pay and pick up the items they're looking for. Tony Dokoupil reports.

articles.title: 67 million expected to take part in Small Business Saturday
articles.description: Black Friday's online sales set a new record this year, but there are some things that shoppers need to buy in stores. Now, 67 million people are expected to take part in Small Business Saturday. Reena Ninan reports.

articles.title: Police now say man killed is not suspected gunman in Alabama mall shooting
articles.description: Police initially said the man shot and killed by officers after a shooting at an Alabama mall on Thanksgiving night was the suspect. But by Friday night, police said he was likely not the gunman – and the suspect is still at large. Kenneth Craig reports.
